2  Summary of Activities for reporting Period (3/2/2004 – 2/2/2005)
 Mining and exploration on Christmas Island is confined to MCI 70/1 which comprises
 of 39 sub-areas known locally as MLs 100 – 140 inclusive with 133 split into 133a
 and 133b and 114, 119 and 120 missing, Figure 1 below.

24.text: Christmas Island is located at 10o 30’ South and 105o 40’ East in the northern Indian

25.text: Ocean approximately 2,600 kms north west of Perth and 340 kms south of Jakarta in

29.text: 4.1  Geology of Phosphate Resources on Christmas Island

30.text: The phosphate deposits at Christmas Island are of organic origin, mainly derived from

31.text: bird guano, and are found along terraces and the flat central plateau areas overlying

32.text: the  limestone  bedrock.  Figure  3  below  shows  the  formation  of  the  phosphate  at

Figure 2. Location of Christmas Island.

 4.1  Geology of Phosphate Resources on Christmas Island
 The phosphate deposits at Christmas Island are of organic origin, mainly derived from
 bird guano, and are found along terraces and the flat central plateau areas overlying
 the  limestone  bedrock.  Figure  3  below  shows  the  formation  of  the  phosphate  at

 4.2  Exploration Methods
 During  the  report  period  the  main  exploration  activity  was  aircore  drilling.    The
 drilling  data  was  processed  to  produce  resource  estimates  using  MineMap  software
 and  ore  blocks  and  drilling  data  entered  into  Arcview  GIS  databases  for  mine
 During  the  reported  period  a  total  of  1089  aircore  holes  were  drilled  for  a  total  of
 4,131m with 4,344 samples sent for assay.
 4.2.1.1  Drilling Method

28.text: ready for resource estimation using either Surpac or MineMap software packages.

4.text: The sample upon arrival at the laboratory is allowed to dry in the air overnight.  After

5.text: air drying the sample is split using a riffle to approximately 1 kg. The entire sample is

6.text: then crushed using a jaw crusher to <3 mm.  This crushed sample is then split using

7.text: another riffle to approximately 200 gms and dried for several hours under an infra-red

text:
The sample upon arrival at the laboratory is allowed to dry in the air overnight.  After
 air drying the sample is split using a riffle to approximately 1 kg. The entire sample is
 then crushed using a jaw crusher to <3 mm.  This crushed sample is then split using
 another riffle to approximately 200 gms and dried for several hours under an infra-red

8.text: lamp.  The dried sample is then ground using a pulveriser down to –300#.

10.text: A 0.5gm sample of the pulverised powder is then dissolved in 17ml of acid solution

11.text: on a hotplate for 10-12 minutes and then cooled. This acid solution is composed as

12.text: follows:-  7ml  of  70%  perchloric  acid,  5ml  of  70%  nitric  acid  and  5ml  of  30%

13.text: hydrochloric  acid.    This  cooled  solution  is  then  flushed  into  a  flask  and  diluted  to

14.text: 250ml before being shaken and decanted into a disposable 4ml cup ready for reading

15.text: by a Technicon Autoanalyser II colorimeter for P2O5, Al2O3 and Fe2O3.

16.text: Standard solutions at 37% P2O5 and 33% P2O5 are both placed in the analyser after

17.text: every 20th sample to check the colorimeter calibration.

18.text: The analysis results from the samples are hand recorded on the drill log sheets and

19.text: passed back to the Mine Planning Department for data processing.

21.text: A bulk density of 1.4 is used to estimate both in-situ and dump material wet tonnes

22.text: from  volumes.    This  value  is  based  on  measurements  taken  of  numerous  samples

26.text: drilled.  These drilling databases comprise a series of three Excel spreadsheets that

40.text: PRL’s  secondary  mining  techniques  aim  to  recover  as  much  as  possible  of  the

41.text: remnants  left  behind.    The  high  grade  of  this  material  makes  it  worthwhile  even

42.text: though mining productivities are generally very low.

43.text: Four types of secondary mining phosphate have been identified at South Point. (See

45.text: 1.  High grade phosphate between pinnacles blocked by large limestone boulders

46.text: 2.  High grade phosphate deep down between pinnacles

47.text: 3.  Lower grade phosphate (especially CAS) probably bought in from Field 17 to be

49.text: 4.  High grade phosphate buried below limestone rafts left after pinnacles have been

51.text: 5.  Pebble phosphate scree washed down from higher levels

text:
PRL’s  secondary  mining  techniques  aim  to  recover  as  much  as  possible  of  the
 remnants  left  behind.    The  high  grade  of  this  material  makes  it  worthwhile  even
 though mining productivities are generally very low.
 Four types of secondary mining phosphate have been identified at South Point. (See
 1.  High grade phosphate between pinnacles blocked by large limestone boulders
 2.  High grade phosphate deep down between pinnacles
 3.  Lower grade phosphate (especially CAS) probably bought in from Field 17 to be
 used as back-fill along tracks
 4.  High grade phosphate buried below limestone rafts left after pinnacles have been
 almost totally replaced by apatite.
 5.  Pebble phosphate scree washed down from higher levels

36.text: old tracks, roads and between the pinnacles surrounding the tracks in areas that were

37.text: already “mined out” by earlier miners.  This material costs significantly more to mine

38.text: than the Field 17 phosphate and would be uneconomic to process and sell alone as

39.text: CIRP33 without blending with the low cost Field 17 phosphate.

21.text: The  dumps  are  being  progressively  surveyed  using  the  GPS  equipment  to  more

22.text: accurately  determine  the  actual  dump  volumes  and  tonnes.    Due  to  the  lack  of  a

23.text: properly trained surveyor for most of the year and repeated equipment failures this

24.text: surveying will not be available until the next reporting period.

25.text: The following formula was used to calculate Dry tonnes:

26.text: Dry tonnes = Wet tonnes x 0.65 x Mining recovery

27.text: Where the mining recovery is 80% for in-situ and 100% for dumps.

28.text: These resource estimates are termed Inferred according to the JORC code of reporting

30.text: A full listing of these resource blocks in Wet and Dry tonnes is shown in Table 4.

Where  the  Adjusted  hole  depth  =  average  hole  depth  of  the  holes  in  the  block
 discounted by 40% if the hole depth exceeds 3m to reflect “conical” dump shapes to
 The  dumps  are  being  progressively  surveyed  using  the  GPS  equipment  to  more
 accurately  determine  the  actual  dump  volumes  and  tonnes.    Due  to  the  lack  of  a
 properly trained surveyor for most of the year and repeated equipment failures this
 surveying will not be available until the next reporting period.
 The following formula was used to calculate Dry tonnes:
 Dry tonnes = Wet tonnes x 0.65 x Mining recovery
 Where the mining recovery is 80% for in-situ and 100% for dumps.
 These resource estimates are termed Inferred according to the JORC code of reporting
 Mineral Resources and Ore Reserves.
 A full listing of these resource blocks in Wet and Dry tonnes is shown in Table 4.

4.3.1.1  Resource Calculations
 As this drilling is only a reconnaissance drilling program with the hole spacing being
 irregular  and  wide  spaced,  no  attempt  was  made  to  rigorously  calculate  resource
 The  drilling  was  plotted  in  Arcview  with  1987  and  1997  aerial  photography  as  an
 underlay.  The hole depths were shown graphically to mainly distinguish dumps and
 in-situ, with >3m depth defined as dump, <3m in-situ.  The features drilled were then
 digitised using the photography as a guide, i.e. dumps and in-situ blocks and where
 several  holes  indicated  possible  commercial  grade  phosphate,  these  areas  were
